statement.p: Many substances are metabolized by our body so that the amount of the substance in our system decreases exponentially. Sometimes studies state this in terms of "half-life", and sometimes as an hourly rate of decrease.
Where \displaystyle{A} is the initial amount, \displaystyle{H}{L} is the half-life in hours, \displaystyle{t} is the time in hours, and \displaystyle{r} is the hourly rate of decrease.
Suppose a substance has a half-life of 6 hours.
What is the hourly decay rate, to the nearest tenth of a percent?

solution.p: We can start by dividing both sides by the initial amount \displaystyle{A}.
Since the time has to be the same on both sides, let \displaystyle{t}={1}.
If the half-life is 6 hours, then we get \displaystyle{r}={1}-{\left(\frac{{1}}{{2}}\right)}^{{\frac{{1}}{{6}}}}\approx{0.10910128185966}
If we round to the nearest tenth of a percent, then the rate of decrease, \displaystyle{r}\approx{10.9}\%.
